Human Readability of Data Files
Michael Robert Gryk

 #balisage2022
subs.rawText:
Human Readability of Data Files
Michael Robert Gryk

subs.text:
MG: Recap of STAR format
Thinking now about human readability: how do we define that?
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
MG: Recap of STAR format
Thinking now about human readability: how do we define that?
#balisage2022

subs.text:
MG: Shows various examples of formats called "human readable" sans definitions
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
MG: Shows various examples of formats called "human readable" sans definitions
#balisage2022

subs.text:
MG: Look at readability in the context of human texts, e.g.Flesch metric based on average sentent length, number of affixes, number of references to people
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
MG: Look at readability in the context of human texts, e.g.Flesch metric based on average sentent length, number of affixes, number of references to people
#balisage2022

subs.text:
MG: Developed to "reading ease" based on average words per sentence, average syllables per word
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
MG: Developed to "reading ease" based on average words per sentence, average syllables per word
#balisage2022

subs.text:
MG: Take this idea and apply to data formats? How?
Analogy to sentences, words, syllables?
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
MG: Take this idea and apply to data formats? How?
Analogy to sentences, words, syllables?
#balisage2022

subs.text:
MG: In STAR: names/identifiers, data values, comments, syntactical constructs
What to count? Identifiers: more is better?
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
MG: In STAR: names/identifiers, data values, comments, syntactical constructs
What to count? Identifiers: more is better?
#balisage2022

subs.text:
MG: For syntax elements, seems less is better
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
MG: For syntax elements, seems less is better
#balisage2022

subs.text:
MG: characters in data names + value divided by total characters (minus whitespace and comments)
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
MG: characters in data names + value divided by total characters (minus whitespace and comments)
#balisage2022

comments, white space

subs.text:
AN: Let's talk about clean up

Normalize
Tweak
Encode (=>UTF8)

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
AN: Let's talk about clean up

Normalize
Tweak
Encode (=>UTF8)

#balisage2022

subs.text:
AN: Normalization
Pull in XInclude links, add targets to xproc filter to skip the included links
Easy, right?

Um... source has its own file protocol URIs
With lots of extra characters 

So... file renaming step which also needs to fix the refs
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
AN: Normalization
Pull in XInclude links, add targets to xproc filter to skip the included links
Easy, right?

Um... source has its own file protocol URIs
With lots of extra characters 

So... file renaming step which also needs to fix the refs
#balisage2022

subs.text:
AN: Encoding
Just serialize XML in UTF-8

Uh: XIncluded bits included decades of character entities, but with DOCTYPEs that defined them commented out and the commented out things had wrong names...

So: Use TagSoup to add in right DOCTYPEs

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
AN: Encoding
Just serialize XML in UTF-8

Uh: XIncluded bits included decades of character entities, but with DOCTYPEs that defined them commented out and the commented out things had wrong names...

So: Use TagSoup to add in right DOCTYPEs

#balisage2022

subs.text:
JK: We learned a LOT more than we ever thought:

Identify ALL stakeholders at start w DIRECT rep participating in project

Project teams might have own ideas of XML best practices, etc.

Ensure stakeholder has resources + training

...

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JK: We learned a LOT more than we ever thought:

Identify ALL stakeholders at start w DIRECT rep participating in project

Project teams might have own ideas of XML best practices, etc.

Ensure stakeholder has resources + training

...

#balisage2022

subs.text:
JK: (Lessons, cont)

Stakeholders may change priorities in middle, a lot

Define preferred format for client feedback from the start

Set expectations FIRMLY from the start

Set legal/financial aspects BEFORE starting work

#balisage2022

subs.text:
Designing for Change: Pragmas as an Extensibility Mechanism for Invisible XML
Tomos Hillman, C. M. Sperberg-McQueen, Bethan Tovey-Walsh, Norm Tovey-Walsh 
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
Designing for Change: Pragmas as an Extensibility Mechanism for Invisible XML
Tomos Hillman, C. M. Sperberg-McQueen, Bethan Tovey-Walsh, Norm Tovey-Walsh 
#balisage2022

subs.text:
BTW: Two precepts
1. There are rules for a reason
2. Question authority

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
BTW: Two precepts
1. There are rules for a reason
2. Question authority

#balisage2022

subs.text:
BTW: Want a way to break the rules without imposing our mistakes on the world, a way to innovate but still maintain the standard

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
BTW: Want a way to break the rules without imposing our mistakes on the world, a way to innovate but still maintain the standard

#balisage2022

subs.text:
Pragmas: give instructions to processor, generally out of scope of language semantics

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
Pragmas: give instructions to processor, generally out of scope of language semantics

#balisage2022

subs.text:
BTW: Our proposal for iXML pragmas is NOT official at this point

Pragmas will be ignored by pragma-unaware processors; will be understood by processor that understands that particular pragma

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
BTW: Our proposal for iXML pragmas is NOT official at this point

Pragmas will be ignored by pragma-unaware processors; will be understood by processor that understands that particular pragma

#balisage2022

Pragma is specially structured comment
{[pragma]} vs {normal comment}

subs.rawText:

{[pragma]} vs {normal comment}

subs.text: NTW: Naming Special reserved pragma: {[+pragma myPragma "[link]"]} sets the name to namespace association #balisage2022

NTW: Naming

One goal is to provide mechanism to experiment with things to see how they work

subs.text:

subs.rawText:

subs.text:
Q: iXML spec has several extra-grammatical constraints
Would these be good candidates for pragmatization?
A: Yes, possibly, not sure of details
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
Q: iXML spec has several extra-grammatical constraints
Would these be good candidates for pragmatization?
A: Yes, possibly, not sure of details
#balisage2022

subs.text:
Q: Fan of extensibility, but worried about interoperability. By definition not interoperable. Don't see advantage of adding this to language.
A: There are things that shouldn't be part of language, e.g. ambiguity. Things making sense to particular processors...
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
Q: Fan of extensibility, but worried about interoperability. By definition not interoperable. Don't see advantage of adding this to language.
A: There are things that shouldn't be part of language, e.g. ambiguity. Things making sense to particular processors...
#balisage2022

subs.text:
... Also, if there need to be ways to communicate things to processor, better to have one way than multiple ways.
Believe there are those cases,there are limits to what iXML can express and may WANT different behaviours
[[a debate that will continue; good points on both sides]]
subs.rawText:
... Also, if there need to be ways to communicate things to processor, better to have one way than multiple ways.

subs.text:
MSM A: Why not bring use cases not pragma? Because most such proposals cannot be implemented. Having a proof-of-implementation short-circuits those debates.

subs.text:
RD: Gov vs corporate author: richer information about source author/orgnanization/ministry/department
publisher="Queen's Printer" is not very informative
various contributors and collaborators in play "in cooperation with", "prepared by", etc.

subs.text:

Important to be able to record this
Also want to know creator/provenance of metadata too

subs.rawText:

subs.text:
JT: Client side libraries? Have to be in memory; doesn't scale to large websites. Google? elasticsearch? Other issues. Decided to build our own: staticSearch, client side website search
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Client side libraries? Have to be in memory; doesn't scale to large websites. Google? elasticsearch? Other issues. Decided to build our own: staticSearch, client side website search

subs.text:
JT: staticSearch XSLT/Ant process to generated inverted index of JSON files

Has stemming in multiple languages, wildcards, exact phrases, boolean, configurable filters, contextual...

Every search is bookmarkable URL

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: staticSearch XSLT/Ant process to generated inverted index of JSON files

Has stemming in multiple languages, wildcards, exact phrases, boolean, configurable filters, contextual...

Every search is bookmarkable URL

#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: 
Input: collection of WF HTML5 in XHTML namespace
Plus: configuration file
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: 
Input: collection of WF HTML5 in XHTML namespace
Plus: configuration file
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: rules tell you what to exclude (default is index everything), contexts to give labels (use match patterns)
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: rules tell you what to exclude (default is index everything), contexts to give labels (use match patterns)
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Stemming using own implementation of Porter2 plus "diacritic" stemmer and "identity" stemmer, can also use your own (XSLT + JavaScript); in config
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Stemming using own implementation of Porter2 plus "diacritic" stemmer and "identity" stemmer, can also use your own (XSLT + JavaScript); in config
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Create "inverted index" JSON files, per stem gets instances; fetched one by one by JavaScript in search
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Create "inverted index" JSON files, per stem gets instances; fetched one by one by JavaScript in search
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Create other additional information during indexing: list of titles, list of all (unstemmed) words (used for wildcarding via regex)
#ballisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Create other additional information during indexing: list of titles, list of all (unstemmed) words (used for wildcarding via regex)
#ballisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Filters and controls generated during indexing; can be used to build the search page
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Filters and controls generated during indexing; can be used to build the search page
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Considerations
Limiting factor is titles (e.g. 170K pages project => 15MB titles file)
No easy way to show matches in document
Context-specific searches, no conditional logic for filters
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Considerations

No easy way to show matches in document
Context-specific searches, no conditional logic for filters
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Solution for context-specific search is separate search pages over different parts (plus more generic for whole site)

subs.text:
BTW: iXML 1.0
What's it for? 
"What if you could see everything as XML?"
Recognizing abstractions: these things are "the same"
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
BTW: iXML 1.0
What's it for? 
"What if you could see everything as XML?"
Recognizing abstractions: these things are "the same"
#balisage2022

subs.text:
BTW: But also need to understand abstractions in context, which changes their interpretation
Abstractions in context = seeing things as XML
Make this visible to the computer
#balisage2022

Extend infrastructure

Welcome to join group, sign up at W3C

subs.text:
EBB: Machine-assisted collation; here the various publications of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Machine-assisted collation; here the various publications of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Gothenburg model of computer-aided collation
1. Tokenization (Smallest unit of comparison)
2. Normalization (e.g. & = and)
3. Alignment (chunking, identifiable start/end pts)]
4. Analysis
5. Visualization
Iterate
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Gothenburg model of computer-aided collation
1. Tokenization (Smallest unit of comparison)
2. Normalization (e.g. & = and)
3. Alignment (chunking, identifiable start/end pts)]
4. Analysis
5. Visualization
Iterate
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Metaphor: collation as weaving
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Metaphor: collation as weaving
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Tokenization; we need to be able to intervene in tokenization and normalization as part of our scholarship
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Tokenization; we need to be able to intervene in tokenization and normalization as part of our scholarship
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: When to make interventions? Pre- vs Post-?
Pre-processing better, but can go overboard and make new problems
Post-processing with XSLT? Yes, with care
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: When to make interventions? Pre- vs Post-?
Pre-processing better, but can go overboard and make new problems
Post-processing with XSLT? Yes, with care
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Tokenization and alignment is a research method
More than one way to do it
So scholars/programmers: share your algorithms
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Tokenization and alignment is a research method
More than one way to do it
So scholars/programmers: share your algorithms

subs.text:
EBB: Error correction is cyclical and hard
Need to document errors and interventions
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Machine-assisted processes need a lot of documentation

subs.text:
Excuse for shout-out to my talk later in the week (Metadata for Creators), which is all about instrumentation of processes subject to a lot of cyclical tweakage
